title: In North Dakota, a Tale of Oil, Corruption and Death

media.caption: Tex G. Hall at the Annual Bakken Oil and Gas Expo in April. He proudly advocated oil development on tribal land.
Left to right, Marilyn Hudson, Theodora Birdbear and Joletta Birdbear at the Three Tribes Museum. All three women became critics of Mr. Hall's dealings with the oil industry.
Tribal members and veterans in a salute on Memorial Day this year. In the rear sits a 96-foot yacht considered by tribal members to be a symbol of their leaders' misplaced spending priorities.
Oil rigs and freshly graded roads near the Fort Berthold Reservation boundary. The reservation sits atop a particularly sweet spot of the Bakken shale formation.
More than 1,370 oil wells, shown here in yellow, have been drilled on the Fort Berthold Indian Reservation.
An oil tanker truck and tanker train cars on the reservation. Wells there are pumping about 386,000 barrels of oil a day, a third of North Dakota’s output.
James Henrikson and Sarah Creveling, his wife and business partner. Mr. Henrikson came to the reservation with a string of marriages, failed businesses and arrests in several states behind him.
Kristopher Clarke worked for Mr. Henrikson but planned to leave the company. He vanished, and his body was never found. Mr. Henrikson has been charged with murder for hire in his death.
Mr. Hall at an event in 2013 with his girlfriend, Tiffiany Johnson, right, and her daughter, Peyton Rose Martin. Ms. Johnson served as chief financial officer of Mr. Hall's company, Maheshu Energy.
Edmund Baker, the reservation’s environmental director. After he halted construction of a waste landfill and convened a community hearing, tribal leaders effectively excommunicated him, he said.

Douglas Carlile on his farm. According to police records, he had been involved in a $2 million oil development deal with Mr. Henrikson, but planned to buy him out. Instead, he ended up dead, murdered in his kitchen.
Calvin Grinnell, curator of the Three Tribes Museum, on his elderly mother’s land that was the subject of a dispute between Mr. Henrikson and Mr. Carlile.

Mr. Henrikson after his arrest early this year on weapons charges. He has since been indicted on two counts of murder for hire, four counts each of conspiracy and of solicitation to commit murder for hire, and one count of conspiracy to distribute heroin.
Mark N. Fox as he was sworn in as tribal chairman last month. Mr. Fox ran on a platform  emphasizing good governance and greater oversight of the oil industry.
The site for a planned oil refinery on the Fort Berthold Reservation. Its future is being newly debated with the change in tribal government.

adx_keywords: Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline;Fort Berthold Indian Reservation (ND);Hall, Tex G;Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides;Henrikson, James (1979- );Hydraulic Fracturing;Series;Native Americans;Bakken Shale Field (ND);Spokane (Wash);North Dakota;Creveling, Sarah M (1986- );Clarke, Kristopher David (1983- );Carlile, Douglas (1950-2013);Mandan, Hidatsa, and Arikara Nation;Corruption (Institutional);Black-Gold Rush (Series)
abstract: Tex G. Hall, a tribal chief connected to the oil industry, has pushed profits on the Fort Berthold Reservation. But accusations of corruption and murder for hire have upended business as usual.

byline: By KEVIN SACK, SHERI FINK, PAM BELLUCK and ADAM NOSSITER
title: How Ebola Roared Back

media.copyright: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
media.caption: Joseph S. Gbembo at a cemetery for Ebola victims in Foya, Liberia. His mother and three other relatives are buried there. The Gbembo lost 17 family members to Ebola in cases stretching from Sierra Leone to Liberia’s capital, Monrovia.

media.copyright: Jessica McGowan for The New York Times
media.caption: Dr. Pierre Rollin, the top Ebola expert at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, believed in early May that the outbreak in West Africa seemed to be burning itself out.

media.copyright: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
media.caption: The village of Meliandou, Guinea, where a 1-year-old boy named Emile Ouamouno came down with symptoms consistent with Ebola and died in late December 2013. Emile is considered Patient Zero in the current outbreak across Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia.

media.copyright: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
media.caption: A list of the people suspected to have died of Ebola in and around the village of Meliandou, Guinea, during the current outbreak. The list, transcribed by a resident of Meliandou, begins with 1-year-old Emile Ouamouno, believed to be Patient Zero of the outbreak.

media.copyright: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
media.caption: A villager on a path used to cross between Sierra Leone and Guinea. Relatively unfettered passage among those countries and Liberia has contributed to an Ebola outbreak.

Finda Nyuma, left, with her half sister Finda Focko at a village celebration in Sierra Leone. Ms. Nyuma died of Ebola around April 8; dying soon after were her husband, a grandson, several women who had prepared her body for burial and others exposed to them.

media.copyright: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
media.caption: Finda Focko with her 2-year-old grandson, Kelvin, in Koindu, Sierra Leone. Ms. Focko had helped prepare the body of her half sister Finda  Nyuma for burial but did not contract Ebola.

media.copyright: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
media.caption: The nurse Nafisatu S. Jabbie with a baby she had delivered at a community health center in Koindu, Sierra Leone. Two nurses at the clinic died caring for patients that had Ebola. A relative of Finda Nyuma was one of the clinic's first confirmed Ebola cases.

media.copyright: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
media.caption: A man pointing to the grave of Finda Nyuma in Kpondu, Sierra Leone. The funeral of Ms. Nyuma, a traditional faith healer, led to other infections.

media.copyright: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
media.caption: Ebola-prevention advice at Guéckédou Hospital in Guinea, where some of the first suspected cases of the outbreak were treated. Dr. Kalissa N’fansoumane, the hospital director, said, “We thought it was a mysterious disease."

media.copyright: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
media.caption: Health workers in protective suits at the Doctors Without Borders treatment center in Kailahun, Sierra Leone. Wearing such suits in tropical heat makes it difficult to work with Ebola patients for long stretches.

media.copyright: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
media.caption: Residents of the Kailahun district of Sierra Leone, near the Guinean border, at the Under 5 clinic waiting for passes to travel out of their Ebola quarantine areas. Health officials stationed here investigated the first confirmed cases of the outbreak in Sierra Leone.

media.copyright: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
media.caption: A view from Nongoa, Guinea, where one can cross the Makona River into Sierra Leone by dugout canoe. It is one of several ways to easily move among the countries and Liberia.

media.copyright: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
media.caption: A health worker at Foya-Borma Hospital in Foya, Liberia, testing the blood of a 40-year-old man suspected of having Ebola who was recently brought in by wheelbarrow. He did not contract Ebola and was released Monday.  Liberia's first known Ebola patient was brought to Foya-Borma in March.
